issues.title: Consistency Proofs not well defined
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
There is an editors note:

> Editors note: tree-size-1, could be omitted, if an inclusion-proof is always present, since the inclusion proof contains, tree-size-1.

This note needs to be addressed with spec text.

This is a WGLC blocking issue.

comments.author: robinbryce
comments.body:
Do you think tree-size-1, tree-size-2 and path are sufficient to do consistency proofs for merkle mountain ranges ?

MMR's are discussed [here](https://github.com/opentimestamps/opentimestamps-server/blob/master/doc/merkle-mountain-range.md) and [also here](https://github.com/mimblewimble/grin/blob/master/doc/mmr.md) in the context of blockchains but they seem to be generally a good thing.

I haven't found a good clear description of what a consistency proof would look like for MMR's, but I *think* its sufficient to just prove inclusion of prior 'peaks' in the new log state at tree-size-2.  And that can just catenate the paths for each peak. Verification would just 'run off the end' if any single sub path was invalid. At least if the interior nodes commit to log position as H(POSITION, H-LEFT-CHILD, RIGHT-CHILD), I think that is all that is needed.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
No. In this draft Consistency Proofs are limited to RFC9162 definition.

A separate document would be needed to describe MMRs as a VDS.

comments.author: robinbryce
comments.body: Understood, I think I simply meant could the representation for the proof data be sensibly re-used in a separate document. the verification process would of course need to be described separately. but yes, this issue isn't the place for that conversation then.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
@robinbryce its possible it could be, but even if the proofs were the same, the algorithm should be different, because the intended use is different.

The registry this draft establishes is 2 layers:

- first layer is the data structure algorithm
- second layer is the proof types that data structure supports

to use the draft, you always need to start by address the first layer, and then mapping first layer code points to second layer code points.

its possible the second layer proof definitions could look very similar, such as EC2 and OKP public keys both have "x" and "d"... but the meaning of "x" and "d" comes from the "kty" values, not from "x" or "y", alone.

comments.author: robinbryce
comments.body: That's a really helpful pointer. Thanks!

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
The armored witness stuff seems to be using the consistency proofs like this, to help with the monitoring and auditing use case, for go:

- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SOfOe_z37jQ
- https://github.com/C2SP/C2SP/pull/66

issues.title: Detached Payload in Consistency Proofs
issues.author: OR13
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/Jr10No1nSA35PxhBzYmx49oYuuY/

Some discussion on the list suggests that both inclusion and consistency proofs should have detached payloads.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: Changes suggested in Section 5.3.1 https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-ietf-cose-merkle-tree-proofs-05#section-5.3.1-8

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: Lets add a sentence explaining why consistency proof needs to be attached, and that verifying a consistency proof starts with having 2 roots... so detaching is not recommended

comments.author: robinbryce
comments.body:
This is very specific to this particular VDS. And I still I don't know why it would not be recommended. The reasons it make sense to require the root of a inclusion proof be generated as part of signature verification seem to apply at least to the second root.

I supsect the reason here is "because this is how we did it" ? (and that is fine, but if so lets not alude to something more by accident)

comments.author: robinbryce
comments.body: I'll try a pr for this this week, unless someone beats me to i

comments.author: ad-l
comments.body:
We discussed this on the editor call and we think that it is not really an issue that for the RFC9162 algorithm the inclusion proof has detached signature whereas consistency proofs have attached signatures, as for consistency you need an explicit comparison point (that you can't locally recompute), whereas inclusion proofs we explicitly want the verifier to recompute.

However, there is one change we could do to clarify the requirements around this. Currently, we explain why all inclusion proofs should use detached payloads in 5.2, even though we don't say this requirement applies to all VDS, not just RFC9162_SHA256. So we should clarify this, and also say (possibly in 5.3) that consistency proofs may or may not use detached payloads, depending on the VDS.

comments.author: SteveLasker
comments.body: Editor's call note: For RFC9162 consistency proofs, we should have an attached payload, which is the new merkletree head, for this particular format.

issues.title: Mention of 'COSE Algorithms' in the IANA request
issues.author: henkbirkholz
issues.body: Somehow the notion of 'COSE Algorithms' snug into the IANA request text. AFAIK, that does not really make sense here.

issues.title: Define a normative value of typ(6) for COSE Merkle Proofs
issues.author: achamayou
issues.body:
Although relying parties can implicitly check for the presence of `vds(395)` to decide if a COSE document is a COSE Merkle Proof, I think it would be clearer and less open to ambiguity to define a specific value of `typ(6)`.

Having validators check for the presence of fields to decide what they are looking is making implementation more error prone than necessary. It would be possible to construct a document that would have both a `vds(395)` and the TBD fields of COSE Hash Envelope for example, and whose validation may end up depending on the order in which implementations check for the presence of fields. Dispatching on `typ` values is more likely to be implemented consistently.

5.2.1 makes the following suggestion:

> Profiles of proof signatures are
> encouraged to make additional protected header parameters mandatory,
> to ensure that claims are processed with their intended semantics.
> One way to include this information in the COSE structure is use of
> the typ (type) Header Parameter, see
> [I-D.ietf-cose-typ-header-parameter] and the similar guidance

But none of the proposed profiles have defined a `typ`, which would be redundant with `vds(395)`.

reviews.author: JAG-UK
reviews.body: I have made the same single comment 5 times. Sorry about that, but it has many tentacles.

comments.body: Wouldn't it be better/simpler for this to ALWAYS be a list and sometimes only have 1 element?
Wouldn't it be better/simpler for this to ALWAYS be a list and sometimes only have 1 element?
Wouldn't it be better/simpler for this to ALWAYS be a list and sometimes only have 1 element?
Wouldn't it be better/simpler for this to ALWAYS be a list and sometimes only have 1 element?
Wouldn't it be better/simpler for this to ALWAYS be a list and sometimes only have 1 element?
I agree, this was just my first attempt at an update... and I wanted to hear from @henkbirkholz and other CBOR / COSE experts on how best to address this.

Technically, that would be:

```
bstr / [ 2* bstr ]
```
or
```
one-or-more<T> = T / [ 2* T ]
one-or-more<bstr> 
```
and not
```
[ + bstr ]
```

as illustrated in https://github.com/ietf-wg-scitt/draft-ietf-scitt-architecture/issues/109#issue-1935673877

```suggestion
  &(consistency-proof: TBD_3) => consistency-proofs
```

```suggestion
* kid (label: 4): OPTIONAL. Key identifier. Value type: bstr
* crit (label: 2): OPTIONAL. Criticality marker. Value type: [ + label ]
```

comments.body:
A minor edit to follow up on your minor edit.

```suggestion
: A verifiable process, that proves properties of a Verifiable Data Structure.
```

As an aside, can a Proof Type only handle a Verifiable Data Structure, not more than one? That is implied by the edit here.

```suggestion
digital signature algorithm `alg` has the appropriate strength to secure receipts.
```
"Might require" is unclear; I believe this refers to the inclusion of a validity period in the information authenticated by the receipt, not an abstract requirement. May go back to "may include" ?

```suggestion
In some cases, receipts MAY include strict validity periods, for example,
```

pulls.title: Remove line on switching VDSes
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body:
I suggest removing the line on migrating between VDSes. I think it's good that the draft addresses an overlap in VDPs. However, I fear that the line I suggest removing might invite people to _not_ worry about security. I think it could be parsed as: "Probably, switching works."

Without the line, I think the draft now emphasizes that (a) you shouldn't expect that overlap in similar concepts leads to the same result, and (b) you must always consider security when migrating.

comments.author: robinbryce
comments.body:
This argument makese sense to me. I am conflicted about re-use too. I raised this PR today: https://github.com/cose-wg/draft-ietf-cose-merkle-tree-proofs/pull/26

It could be seen as either "making things worse" according to this issue, but possibly "threading the needle" by pushing full responsibility for re-use on to the confirming specification.

I am neutral on both this and my own PR, but very interested in the authors comments

pulls.title: re issue#20 make accounting for hash algorithm agility explicit
pulls.author: robinbryce
pulls.body: The example RFC9162 supports hash algorithm agility. This change makes the implied requirement to register each "instantiation" seperately explicit.

comments.body:
```suggestion
an IANA registration must be made for each individually supported algorithm.
```

```suggestion
both "RFC9162_SHA256" and "RFC9162_SHA3_256" require entries in the relevant IANA registries.
```

```suggestion
Where a specification supports a choice of hash algorithm, an IANA registration must be made for each individually supported algorithm.
```

```suggestion
For example, to provide for both SHA256 and SHA3_256 with {{RFC9162}}, both "RFC9162_SHA256" and "RFC9162_SHA3_256" require entries in the relevant registries.
```

pulls.title: issue #20 uint vs int for tree indices and sizes
pulls.author: robinbryce
pulls.body:
Is there a reason the CBOR uses int (cose major type 1) in preference to uint ? If not, I suggest we use uint to preserve the full range of positive values possible.

note: I may need to update the dbor-diag output. If this change is acceptable in principal I am happy to go do that as a requirement to merge.

pulls.title: re issue#20 suggested clarification regarding leaf-index
pulls.author: robinbryce
pulls.body:
Depending on the audience the term leaf-index can be confusing. It is clear in the context of RFC9162.

This PR seeks to make it clear in the inline example for readers that have not absorbed the details of RFC9162

comments.body:
```suggestion
Note that {{RFC9162}} defines that verification MUST fail if leaf-index is >= tree-size, and inclusion proofs are defined only for leaf nodes.
```

reviews.author: OR13
reviews.body: this is a throwaway sentence i think

pulls.title: re issue#20 validity period
pulls.author: robinbryce
pulls.body:
This PR seeks to clearly deliniate the validity period of the signature over the receipt from any potential validity period concept for the proof material itself.

And particularly, to avoid a situation where VDS specifications make it impossible to express a signature validity period because it has "camped" on the appropriate COSE headers for doing so.

comments.author: robinbryce
comments.body: withdrawing after authors feedback

```suggestion
In some cases, receipt signatures MAY include strict validity periods, for example, activation not too far in the future, or expiration, not too far in the past.
```

```suggestion
Instead, if the VDS wishes to express a proof of validity, or freshness, period, the specification MUST define them distinctly from the signature validity claims.
```

```suggestion
In some cases, receipt MAY include strict validity periods, for example, activation not too far in the future, or expiration, not too far in the past.
```
validity periods apply to the full envelope

reviews.author: OR13
reviews.body: Seems like this document is the wrong place to put constraints on claims

comments.body: ...receipt**s**

pulls.title: re issue#20 encourage use of detached payloads for proof formats
pulls.author: robinbryce
pulls.body:
It seems like a generaly strong and useful property that proof formats require that the payload be re-constructed from the proof prior to signature verification

This change adds a single scentence to the example inclusion proof to encourage this.

comments.body:
```suggestion
Specifications are encouraged to make payloads detached when possible, forcing validation-time comparison.
```

pulls.title: Editing after review
pulls.author: felixlinker
pulls.body:
With this PR I address my comments on editing in this review: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/b7ZLpC3U5CNhQscCi6ErDvFk9kg/

Some reasoning.
- I replaced the terms "latest" and "previous" with "newer" and "older." This is in-line with RFC 9126 and emphasizes that consistency proofs about the past can be generated.
- I fixed what I believed to be errors at the beginning of 5.2.1. There, it said "previous" root (I believe correct would be just any root you wish to prove inclusion for) and "tree-size-1" (which I believe should be "tree-size").
- I removed an ambiguous occurrence of the word "signature." I think the text is clearer without it.

comments.body: I also believe it *should* be possible for a consistency proof to show consistency between two arbitrary points in the log. So the 'older' / 'newer' frazing seems like an improvement to me also

```suggestion
In a signed inclusion proof, the payload is the merkle tree root which corresponds to the log at size tree-size.
```

reviews.author: OR13
reviews.body: I think the first sentence could be clearer, but the rest of these changes are improvements.

comments.body:
seeing size tree-size was a bit confusing. Suggestion to change code fragments use `code` formatting.
```suggestion
In a signed inclusion proof, the payload is the merkle tree root which corresponds to the log at size `tree-size`.
```

reviews.author: SteveLasker
reviews.body: LGTM, with, or without the nit suggestion at [line 302](https://github.com/cose-wg/draft-ietf-cose-merkle-tree-proofs/pull/29/files#diff-e456ca8fff23262339949e1ef0e3b1f5c757b63b05b691c26d656654bef76d6fR302)

reviews.author: OR13
reviews.body: lets discuss this in higher bandwidth.

comments.body:
```suggestion
This request to IANA includes a range of labels for COSE header parameters to be "Earmarked for COSE Receipts" so that numbers in that earmark range can be reassigned by IANA based on advice from the designated experts for the COSE Header Parameters registry.
```
We should write the advice that is needed for DEs into this document, if we are requesting them to administer a range.

pulls.title: updated to Henk's ietf email address
pulls.author: henkbirkholz

comments.body:
```suggestion
Detaching the payload forces verifiers to recompute the root from the consistency proof, this protects against implementation errors where the signature is verified but the merkle root does not match the proof.
```
